turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I've got some pictures.  Want to see?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I don't want to see any goddamn pictures.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: Anna will be away at camp. The house will be quiet. It's better when it's quiet.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Tell Annette I'm busy in July.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You should see my appointment book. It got crazy.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: The important thing is that you and Annette need to talk. She needs to see you, and you need to see her.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: You're a good man, Walter. Okay, you did some wrong things, but inside you're a good, decent man.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Maybe I'm not a good man. Maybe inside I'm bad, and I'll always be bad.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I get horny as hell for other women.  I mean I fantasize about raping some beautiful woman.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You don't have to tell me this.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Carlos, I never raped a woman.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: I know. I'm just saying I understand.

turns.speaker: CARLOS
turns.text: It's crazy out there.  Young girls wearing mini this and mini that. Sometimes when I walk down the street and pass some sexy looking woman, she makes me feel like I'm bothering her. She stares down like she's afraid to look at me. Why she do that? Why can't she look me in the face?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Maybe because you're looking her in the face.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Carlos, can I ask you something?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Did you ever... Do you have feelings for Anna?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: In that birch tree is a nest.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: There's little chicks!  You want to see?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: They're extremely aggressive birds. Plus, their habits are rather filthy.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: The mother sure has her hands full.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: When I go bird-watching. It's why I like coming here.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: You'd be surprised how many kinds of birds you'll see here. Last week I saw a purple martin. And the week before that, I saw a solitary vireo. That's rare.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: A solitary vireo. I like that one.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Not too far.  Are you a bird-watcher too?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Me? Nah. I'm more of a people watcher.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Not at first. You would stare at the tops of the trees so intently. Any second I thought you would take off and fly.

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: My daddy likes me home before dark.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It's good to listen to your daddy.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What are you writing in that book?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: A pretty girl like you should have a lot of friends.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Well... not in the common way.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It means uncommon beauty is commonly overlooked. Most people only notice birds with the brightest colors.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You tell me your name, I'll tell you mine.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Why don't you just tell me?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Then you won't mind if I look around.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: I could get a search warrant.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: If you could, you would have brought one today.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Unusual design for a contemporary piece.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Who said I wanted to buy it?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: And when you sit by the window, watching the girls in the little cotton skirts parade by, do you wave your wanger at the girls? Is that when you jerk off?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You can't talk to me like --

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Like a piece of shit? In my eyes, you are a piece of shit. Think anyone would miss you if I threw you out the window right now? I could say you jumped when I came in. Who are they going to believe? Not you, because you'd be a dead piece of shit.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Your ivy. Too much direct sunlight. These plants don't like a lot of sun.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Sure they do. But outside they've got trees around them. The trees shade them from the sun. Of course, the plants enrich the soil around the trees. One of nature's symbiotic relationships.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You going to take me on a nature walk?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Don't be witty.  Yesterday you took the number twelve bus from work, but instead of getting off at your normal stop, for some reason you stayed on. Why did you stay on the bus, Walter?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: This one guy on death row, who I'll call Henry, told me about his last victim. Henry says how he's in the bedroom of a seven-year-old cutie named Adele. Her mother's in the living room watching TV. She's got the volume on so damn high he can hear David Letterman's jokes. Henry puts his hand over Adele's mouth and says, "If you scream, little girl, I'll kill your mother." And of course little Adele doesn't scream, doesn't cry, doesn't make a sound. Then he takes her hand and out they go through the front door.  Ten days later they find Adele's body. Or what's left of it.  You believe in fairy tales?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Neither do I.  What's the one with the woodsman?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Sure you do. He cuts open the wolf's stomach, and the girl steps out alive.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: That's it. Little Red Riding Hood jumps out of the wolf's guts with hardly a scratch.  Ever see a seven-year-old girl sodomized almost in half?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: I'll be asking the questions.  Last night, you hear anything unusual? Screams? Shouts?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: A man was badly beaten across the street. You know anything about that?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: I didn't say what time the assault occurred.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You said last night. I went to bed pretty early.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: The assault took place at approximately seven thirty.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I went to bed around seven.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You could. It'd be a waste of your time, though.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: He I.D.'d the assailant. The description matches you pretty well.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I suppose if you're looking for a male between the ages of thirty and fifty, medium height, medium weight, medium build. Probably not too many men fit that bill.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Just give me a straight answer, Walter, cause the irony goes right over my head.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: That's a nasty scratch on your neck.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You're a cop. Figure it out.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: It's a free country, isn't it?

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Then I'd say you're a lucky fellow.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: Well, I guess I'll be seeing you.

turns.speaker: LUCAS
turns.text: You sure you don't know nothing about this?

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Sergeant Lucas.  May I come in?

turns.speaker: MARY-KAY
turns.text: The new man. I'd keep away from him, if I were you.

turns.speaker: MARY-KAY
turns.text: You don't want to know, but he's damaged goods -- real damaged goods, if you know what I mean.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Yeah, Mary-Kay, I think I do. Thanks a bunch for the advice.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Well, Mary, you're about as helpful as a broken sewer pipe. You do know what runs out of a sewer pipe, don't you?

turns.speaker: MARY-KAY
turns.text: People have the right to know.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: If she's here tomorrow, I'll fucking kill her.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Can I ask how old you are?

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: I will be in three months.  I can't wait. I hate being eleven. It has to be the stupidest age in the world.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: A long time ago, I was sent far away. When they let me come back, all my friends were gone.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: It sounds like you were banished.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Birds are my friends. That sounds egotistical, but they are. Birds know I watch them, but they don't mind because they like being watched... if they know you won't hurt them.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Would you like to sit on my lap?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Would you like to sit on my lap?

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: I'm sure. Thank you all the same.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Do you want me to sit on your lap?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I know a place in the park where only very small birds go. There are no people or dogs or ugly crows and pigeons. It's quiet except for the song of these tiny sparrowlike birds. Would you like me to take you there?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: They could be finches. I don't know. We should go before it gets dark.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: My daddy lets me sit on his lap.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Do you like it when he asks you?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Tell Ms. Kramer what your daddy does.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You said you couldn't make the sound of a solitary vireo. But you did. Beautifully. I heard you.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: What will happen if I do?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Someone will talk to your daddy. And then he'll stop doing those things... the things you don't like.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Your daddy will always love you.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I know because... it's just something I know.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: I don't want to hurt my daddy.

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Do you still want me to sit on your lap?

turns.speaker: ROBIN
turns.text: Can't I stay a little longer?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Do I take "okay" to mean you feel good about working there?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I said the job is okay.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: That's right, you did.  Have you made any friends there?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'm not running for Mr. Popularity.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: You seem a little hostile today.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: No need to call me doctor. I'm a therapist, not a psychiatrist.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Walter, I'd like you to try something for me.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I'd like you to keep a journal.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Diaries have sent too many guys to prison.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Oh. It never crossed my mind.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I thought a journal would encourage you to reflect.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: By reflection we can derive a deeper meaning from our experience in life. We gain greater understanding about ourselves that can lead to making better choices in our relationships, our careers, and our goals.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I wish you'd give it a try.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: You don't like coming here, do you?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: But you don't like coming here. Be honest, Walter.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Good. That's an honest answer. And why don't you like coming here?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Honest? Your cheery personality makes my skin itch.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Is it just my cheery personality that makes your skin itch?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Maybe it's the way I look. Or the sound of my name.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Rosen? I don't have a problem with that.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Because if you did, I know a therapist named Ryan. I also know a therapist named Chung.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: How do you feel about that?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: You have no feelings for your niece?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: She was born after they put me away. How can I have feelings?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Then why are you talking about this?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: What are you afraid will happen?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'm not afraid. I'm just saying that Carlos has a thing for his daughter, and if he isn't careful he's going to suffer.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Have you talked to Carlos about your concerns?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: If I'm not, then what the hell am I doing here?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Why do you think you're here?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You know why. It's part of the parole deal.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Is that what you are angry about?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Talking to you is like riding on a merry-go-round.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: That is a marvelous image, Walter. Because by going in circles we find the things we missed the first time around.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: How long is this going to take?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: We have a few more minutes.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I mean, when will I be normal.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: We have a lot of work to do.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I suppose it's however society defines it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Then how do you know if your patients are getting better?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: What is your idea of being normal?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What is your idea of being a Jew?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Whatever my ideas are of being a Jew is not going to help you.  Why don't we continue this on Thursday.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Then go see a therapist who will tell you you're normal!

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I know you're frustrated, Walter, but --

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: What did you think would happen?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: What did you want to happen?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You know that if anything happens, I spend the rest of my life in prison. No parole, no nothing.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Of course it is! That's why I'm telling you!

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I want you to calm down.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Walter, we'll pick up here next time.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I want to talk about it now.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: We'll talk about it more on Thursday.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Remember when you asked me what my idea of "normal" was?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Now I know. It's when I can see a girl, be near a girl, even talk to a girl... and walk away.  That's my idea of being normal.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I can't move my patients around to accommodate one person.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: If by "problem" you mean your desire for prepubescent girls, yes.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I'd like you to close your eyes.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Close your eyes and let your mind be blank.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Hey, Rosen, you going to hypnotize me?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: No, I am not going to --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Okay. Eyes closed, mind a blank. I'm all yours. Do it, Rosen.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: When I say the word "girl" what is the earliest image that you can remember?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Nothing. Can I open my eyes?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: No. When I say the word "pretty," when I say the word "pleasure," what is the earliest memory you see?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: In your mind, Walter. Take your time.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Where is she? What is she doing? How old --

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: In my bed, Rosen. Where do you think?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: How old are you and your sister?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I'm maybe about six... which would make her four.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Just lying there.  We're taking a nap.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Yes, a nap. Kids do that. You ever take a nap, Rosen?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: What the hell are you doing there?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Did you and your sister often take naps together?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I want you back in your chair! Right now!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I don't like nobody behind my back!

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I'm sorry. I shouldn't have been there.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Walter, what did you do while taking a nap with your sister?

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: Did you touch her? Did you take off her clothes? Did you take off your clothes?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Okay I'll tell you what I did -- just to shut you up!  I smelled her hair.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: That's all. I just liked smelling her hair.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: I meant later... when you two took naps.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: When the two of you held each other. When you were ten or eleven and she was eight or nine. When your parents were out and the two of you were alone... completely alone in that big house.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: All right. A small house... with small rooms.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I smelled her hair. That's it. I just liked smelling her hair.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: She's still really hurt... and angry. I don't know... if she will ever... forgive me. I understand that. I do. I just hope... I just want her to...

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: It's going to take time, Walter.

turns.speaker: ROSEN
turns.text: How do you feel about that?

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: There's something wrong with this picture.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Here's this nice, hard working guy who suddenly appears out of the blue and rides the bus to and from work. I mean, who rides the bus anymore?

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: No weirder than a sharp, young, good- looking woman working in a lumberyard.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Guess I'm not like most women.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: You don't hang out with the other guys.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: You never spoke to me before.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: I thought you were a dyke.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Your windows face south. Northern light is the purest. But southern light is very good.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: You should buy several. I've got shitty light in my place, but my plants don't seem to mind. Light's important, but it's not everything.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: You plan to drink both those beers?

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: My place faces a truck street. I've got cracks in every window from the shaking.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: I go backpacking a lot. Lose myself in the wilderness for a week or two.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: I thought you were just shy, but now I think it's something else.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Why do you want to know?

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Don't you think I should know before we have sex?

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Are you going to tell me your deep dark secret before we have sex?

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: I didn't say I didn't enjoy it.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Of course. Sorry. I'm such a fucking asshole.

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: Don't tell me I'm not a fucking asshole when I know I'm a fucking asshole!

turns.speaker: WALTER
turns.text: You think I have a problem?

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: I thought I'd stay the night.

turns.speaker: VICKI
turns.text: Well, Walter, this is going to sound off-the-wall, but I like to sleep with a man after we fuck.
